title: Michael B. Jordan and Jamie Foxx talk the importance of inclusion in their new movie Just Mercy
text:
After Francis McDormand's iconic Oscar speech that made 'inclusion rider' a hot-button term, Michael B. Jordan was the first actor to adopt it with all of his projects through his company Outlier Society.

Jordan's new film Just Mercy, which he stars in alongside Jamie Foxx and Brie Larson and serves as an executive producer, will become the first major studio film to adopt the inclusion rider, which mandates that women, people of color, LGBTQ people and others from underrepresented groups be considered for cast and crew jobs.

In a wide-ranging interview with Variety, Jordan spoke about what drove him to adopt the inclusion rider.

Inclusion: After Francis McDormand's iconic Oscar speech that made 'inclusion rider' a hot-button term, Michael B. Jordan was the first actor to adopt it with all of his projects through his company Outlier Society

Hollywood first: Jordan's new film Just Mercy, which he stars in alongside Jamie Foxx and Brie Larson and serves as an executive producer, will become the first major studio film to adopt the inclusion rider

'We're always coming from a place of not having power,' says Jordan. 'I was like, man, I want my environment to be a reflection of the world I'm living in.'

'We started figuring out a way to do this, so now if you want to do this project with me, you've got to accept these terms,' he added.

Jordan's company Outlier Society has a first look deal with Warner Bros., the studio producing Just Mercy, and he also helped the studio and its parent company WarnerMedia to adopt the inclusion rider across all divisions of the company.

Story: Just Mercy tells the true story of Bryan Stevenson (Jordan), a renowned civil rights attorney who sets out to free death row inmate Walter McMillan (Foxx)

Just Mercy tells the true story of Bryan Stevenson (Jordan), a renowned civil rights attorney who sets out to free death row inmate Walter McMillan (Foxx).

Director Destin Daniel Cretton (Short Term 12, The Glass Castle) said that the inclusion rider allowed crew members who had worked in the industry for years to finally be the head of their own department.

'They did a kick*** job,' says Cretton. 'That's the thing. These aren't favors that we're giving out. This is us getting to a point where we're finally giving people what they deserve.'

Better environment: Larson, who plays Stevenson's colleague Eva Ansley, said the more inclusive set lead to a much better environment

Larson, who plays Stevenson's colleague Eva Ansley, said the more inclusive set lead to a much better environment.

'What I remember most is sitting as a group — cast, filmmakers, crew — and having these incredibly open, vulnerable conversations when the cameras weren’t rolling, Larson said.

'Conversations that ultimately shaped the course of the filmmaking process in a powerful way. It wouldn’t have been possible in a less inclusive environment,' she added.

Vulnerable: 'What I remember most is sitting as a group — cast, filmmakers, crew — and having these incredibly open, vulnerable conversations when the cameras weren’t rolling, Larson said

Foxx plays Walter McMillian, an Alabama man who was convicted of a murder he did not commit, with the actor revealing he drew on his Texas background for the role.

'It allowed me to understand that when they’re saying "n—–," it’s sort of like very matter of fact,' says Foxx.

'It’s just another Tuesday. You have to have that sensibility to understand who this character is,' he added.

Just Mercy debuts Christmas Day in limited release to qualify for awards season, before expanding nationwide January 10, 2020.
